body.p:
You flatter me much when you say
you will be happy to count me among the few you favor with
an interchange of communication. Though I am pleased to stand in
correspondence with the Rev Isaac Leeser Minister of the Portugese Israelites
in Philadelphia I am much more pleased to communicate with the Editor
of the Occident, and the author of the "Jewish Discourses," and of the "Mosaic
Law" If therefore I am at any time not to remedy in answering your favors
as this feeling would prompt, do not impute it to neglect but to its
true cause inability. It has been inability that has prevented my answering
yours of the 16th till the present moment, and it has been inability that
has forbidden my sending you by opportunity of Mr Joseph an article which
I have but just now been able to commence, and which I promised you
in my last. I know not whether it will suit the Occident, because
although a Jewish subject, it is likely to prove more interesting to the readers
of a British Periodical, it may be called an Essay or Enquiry into the first
settlement of Jews in England. When in London I took some little trouble
in collecting materials for the subject and in the above form they
are much at the service of yourself and of the readers of the Occident
Please let me know by earliest opportunity whether you [?] to
receive it. I would have sent you sermon for publication but
suppose that even now you would be unable to insert it from
the number you have on hand. Will my father's be among those
you intend publishing. English news would lead one to believe

that its remarks are as pertinent now as when delivered. News from
here I can send you but little, A friend who lately paid us a visit, and still
more lately visits Philadelphia (I believe) is pleased to say "altho we Canadians do not
form (here) one of the largest and most influential congregations we prove that
we sufficiently understand what is [?] to the respectability of Synagogue worship
"The building is most striking for its very neat & pretty appearance, marked decorum
pervaded the assembled, and an utter absence of that boisterousness, sometimes
unfortunately prevailing in our larger Synagogues was observable xxx The prayers
were read by the [Hebrew] [?] with an apparent desire to avoid that style which
reminds one so much of the opera and which for time and place is alike
objectionable xxxx It must be highly gratifying to you to know that your
discourses, and general services as reader and teacher are highly spoken of (dont[?]
you think dear friend I have some excuse if I grow vain?) My friend ([?]) continues,
But what pleased me most was to see your pupil (Mouther[?] I Ascher the son
of the Parnass) called us Maphlir[?], The very correct and pleasing name of
his reading afforded me much pleasure." If you wish to give us all a fond
character here you can insert it in your news Items. The name of the writer (tho'
perhaps known to you shall be provided if you require it editorially tho'
I am not sure he would like it (his name) to appear in the Occident for All he says is–"If
you choose, write Mr Leeser what a first rate character stranger gives
you." All the news I can give you of us (should you pronounce that no
news) is that our Parnas is Mr Ascher whose inde[?]able services as Parnas, and
whose jealous endeavors to promote the welfare and quiet of the community
with his colleage Dr David the President are mentioned by all in the highest
terms. They all have been unanimously re-elected. The formation[?] of the new Board of Trustees has also caused general satisfaction
among to the members. These are Messrs S. Benjamin, Simon Hart, and Jesse Joseph,
Treasurer John Levy (re-elected) and Levy Myer Solomons (also re-elected.) During
the late summer an unprecedented[?] number of German Jewish Emigrants visited
Canada, Indigent, and in many cases sick! They provide most services
drain on the funds of our Infant Philanthropic Society, About Thirty
unfortunate persons many with families besides one noatbly[?] pensioner, were
recipients. On [?] that the committee contemplated a Benefit Ball
but have not yet held any [?] of [?]. Should they determine
upon this, they will no doubt make it known in the Occident.
This dear friend is all the news I can scrape together concerning
our precious selves, and I have preferred giving you most of it as
an "Extract from a private communication" because if I had myself

undertaken to "give characters" I should altho' finding much to praise
still find a little to censure–But to other matters. I received last
week a letter from my friend D Benisk now Editor of the Voice of Jews
He writes me that it is to be considerably enlarged and the whole to be
under his management. This last would imply, strange fingers in the Free
and I think this has been the case with the late [?] articles contend
in the Voice. In a letter received from my father the same mail he writes
"I hear that it is the intention of your friend Mr Leeser to visit old
England–Do you know whether this is really the case, I should be most
happy to have it in my power to exercise my great esteem for him."
What am I to reply, dear friend? I hear this for the fist time. He
encloses me a prospectus of Mayer's projected publication–What do
you think of this. There is no doubt I should say that as far as abilities,
Rabbinical and general knowledge so, there is not a man, christian or Jew
who is better able to answer Mr C[?] than this said Hoya. As a
Hebraist he has not I firmly believe his equal. Witness his [Hebrew]
and Hebrew Translation of Mr Cauls Old Paths. Some attribute
the Heb version of the Christian Common Prayer to him but looking
at the style of that sublime composition I should doubt this much
His last articles too in the London Jewish Chronicle are–to make
use of a mysterious old saying "not to be sneezed at. I am more
anxious to see his 1st no. The [?] of state [?] I suppose has
retired purposely to make room for the "faithful missionary" who
will doubtless occupy much room on the tables of the religious
reading world, but the Jewish & Christian, altho' the same apathy
unfortunately exist to [?] [Hebrew] here, as on the subject of an
efficient ministry. With respect to this last the observation
of my father very often seems occurs to me. He very dryly observed one day
"The [Hebrew] to sail them must be [Hebrew] [?]"
and I think he is right. But I sincerely hope this unhealthy
state of things will give way to more worthy & [?] notions
It has done so in many cases let us hope that its observence
will soon be universal.

I informed Mrs Ascher of your invitation not to charge for
the nos, and she denies to acknowledge your politeness–

So you are a reformer. I have not yet seen your November number
but doubt well that the reforms there propounded will shock
orthodox susceptibility but little, and that they are of a practiced
and [?]. I too am a reformer as far as endeavours
which I believe to be consistent and legal, in improving the manner
of Synagogue worship are concerned. I don't think the cause of
orthodoxy would suffer much did conservative Synagogues introduce
quiet & respectability in their services. Orthodoxy by nature
by age, and by character is respectable. Absurd and inconsistent
novelty in the Synagogue is disrefutable in its very essence
and it appears therefore a serious & cruel anomaly that while
all that care [?] devotional feelings prevail in the new [?]
in the old, very much that is calculated to excite disgust
worldly and impure feelings is there observable. But my dear
friend [Hebrew], continue to sound in the unwilling ears
of the [Hebrew], and [?] success must one day follow.

"Prata albicaul camis friunis" Our Canadian winter
approaches in the shape of a few slight snow storms. See too
looks more plentiful in the streets than it did in summer, But
with all its severity speaking from last winters experienced
I like the winter here much. There is a [?] the cold [?]
clearness of atmosphere that renders the season here much more
agreeable and healthy than in London.

I must now bid you good bye dear friend for
the present. Hoping you will write me very soon, and
[?] and that you may receive this [Hebrew]!
me to remember them to you
